That said, new frontier technologies, such as high-performance computing and machine learning, are enabling us to better understand and manage these challenges. We can now analyse and visualise billions of data points to generate comprehensive weather forecasts within a few kilometres, so that warnings are issued earlier and more accurately. I hope to see these technologies become more mainstream to cope with issues such as urban planning, and then perhaps we would have a real opportunity to turn the tide.

Mohan Veloo
VP of Technology
F5 Networks, APCJ

In 2020, the projected rise in cloud computing adoption as the model of choice for modernising IT portfolios will soon turn into a reality, with data from our 2019 State of App Services report indicating that almost nine in 10 organisations globally deployed multi-cloud strategies to facilitate their application delivery needs. With the right multi-cloud strategy in place, organisations are now able to deliver far richer user experiences that ultimately drive revenue growth.

However, cloud-first must always go with a security-first mindset. With cyber-attacks rising rapidly in frequency and scale, hackers have also become far more sophisticated in their attacks. To prevent hackers from dominating the technology landscape, businesses need to invest in a holistic cloud security strategy by opting for providers that understand the current threat landscape impacting applications. This can be achieved by providing detailed insights on a business' application infrastructure, as well as devoting significant tools to secure and maintain their security.

Malina Platon
Managing Director, Asean
UiPath

I predict that robotic process automation (RPA) will be the fastest growing software enterprise category for the second year in a row. Thanks to the technology's growing sophistication and use of AI, the RPA market size could increase by 15-30 per cent as companies start to realise the benefits of automation to their bottom lines and productivity. Linked to this, I hope to see automation become a strategic agenda item at the CEO and Board Level, and we may see more Chief Automation Officers emerge. Lastly, I predict that both companies and educational institutions will take reskilling more seriously and implement steps to prepare their workforce and students for an automated future.

I hope that employees and the business community do not see automation as a negative; rather, they should view automation technologies as positive and beneficial to their daily lives, helping them do more with less. This mindset should continue to extend to universities and other learning institutions as well as company HR departments who are in charge of upskilling their employees.

Andrew Wong
VP, Airlines, Asia Pacific
Honeywell Aerospace

While the value of data is growing in appreciation across industries, the sheer abundance of available data can be overwhelming for companies and difficult to apply in smart ways. What we hope will not materialise is a limiting mindset when it comes to the value of business data. While it's challenging to harness all this data, what we don't want to see are companies focusing solely on a select few areas that deliver short-term success.

Rather, we predict that businesses will feel more empowered than ever before and view 2020 as a breakthrough opportunity to use connectivity, data and analytics as tools for sweeping innovation and positive change. Particularly in the aviation industry, technology will serve as a conduit to bring different sources of data together agnostically and turn the analysed information into prescriptive action for aviation companies, leading to benefits like greater efficiency and safety in flight operations. The result will be unprecedented efficiencies and savings in the industry. We strongly believe data will lead to more action in 2020.

Sanjay K Deshmukh
VP and MD, Southeast Asia and Korea
VMware

As businesses continue to push forward in their digital transformation journeys in Singapore, we would like to see companies prioritise digital enablement of the workforce by empowering them with a "Digital Workspace". This will help companies transform the way their employees work and unleash employee productivity, ensuring sustained business and economic success.

2020 is also a watershed moment for the world as the Paris climate agreement comes into effect this year. It is my hope that with the help of technology, we will be able to make a breakthrough in mitigating our impact on the climate, just like how virtualisation technology delivered unprecedented energy and carbon emissions reduction when it was first introduced nearly three decades ago.

Lim Soon Hock
Managing Director
PLAN-B ICAG

I would like to see more concrete and substantial actions by nations to tackle climate change, dealing with greenhouse-gas-emissions mitigation, adaptation and finance. We are already feeling the adverse and often disastrous impacts of climate change. Unless countries take steps to mitigate global warming, there will be more and larger calamities, likely to be on a global scale.

I hope the US-China trade war will not deteriorate and will be averted during President Donald Trump's tenure of office, to return the world to the normal of open trade and less (if not no) protectionism. The global economy will be further impacted if this trade dispute is not resolved.

As a small island nation, Singapore is vulnerable to the debilitating threats of climate change and the US-China trade war. My wish is that these challenges will be tackled with a levelheaded and objective approach by all concerned, to allow Singapore the needed space to continue to prosper in the years ahead.

Andrew Chan
Founder and CEO
ACI HR Solutions

2019 was a turbulent one with geopolitical issues dominating headlines and putting pressure on the economy and employment once again. I hope 2020 will bring stability with Brexit to finally conclude, the US-China trade war to cease and the tensions in Hong Kong to ease. The threat that I hope will not materialise is the escalation in tensions between the US and Iran, which potentially could bring about some catastrophic results.

Soong Chuan Sheng
General Manager
Klook Southeast Asia

The idea of solo travel is, to some, fairly daunting, and often reserved for seasoned executives, uninhibited backpackers and intrepid researchers. But our recent Solo Travel study revealed that 76 per cent of people globally (of all ages and nationality, and both male and female) have either travelled alone or are considering it. We expect this trend to continue to grow and evolve alongside its business opportunities.

On the other hand, overtourism continues to be a problem for many destinations, with different factors coming into play. Governments and local authorities have sought to control tourist numbers, closing off destinations to help rehabilitate the environment. Through technology, destinations are now empowered to combat this - by understanding travel patterns, leveraging data and promoting off-the-beaten path experiences.

Dora Hoan
CEO
Best World International Ltd

I predict that in 2020 and beyond, China's initiatives in leveraging advanced technologies such as 5G and AI, and as a leader embracing a completely cashless and autonomous retail world, will bring huge economic impacts to the East and South-East Asian economies. Singapore stands to gain if we manage to seize and maximise these opportunities.

However, as technology evolves, cyber-criminals will become more and more pervasive and sophisticated. Small to medium-sized organisations with "weaker" anti-risk solutions will become their new targets. Any economic losses and social panic would be undesirable. A strong risk mitigation strategy is vital to ensure secure growth.

Roshni Mahtani
Founder & Group CEO
theAsianparent

With the dawn of a new decade, I hope to see more purpose-driven startups rising to tackle the challenges our world faces. At theAsianparent, we are determined to contribute to the community by tackling stillbirths in the region. The world needs more disruptive solutions that will positively change lives and alleviate the various crises that we face. More venture capital is required to push the boundaries of innovation. However, funding might not be as readily available going forward - an outcome that hopefully doesn't materialise, for progress and betterment of our world.

Henry Tan
Group CEO
Nexia TS

2020 is a year of challenges. I believe the economy will be in for a correction. This is because of the effects of economic slowdown in UK and Europe as a result of Brexit uncertainty; the trade war between US and China; and the inward-looking and protectionist stance of governments in major countries. This is not something I look forward to but it looks imminent. On the brighter side, I believe the digital economy will continue to grow and create new jobs and also bring out new entrants to the markets, fuelling more startups. In Singapore, we look forward to seeing the new technological changes and innovative product offerings with the issue of digital banking licences.

Amit Saberwal
Founder and CEO
RedDoorz

Technology has heavily influenced change in the travel and hospitality sector; so much so that expectations of modern travellers have evolved. In addition to making improvements to back-end and operational technology, new digital technologies such as IoT and AI will become ever more prevalent in order to deliver a more seamless guest experience during the search, booking and stay phase.

We hope brands don't back-peddle on green efforts in favour of reducing costs; we don't want to see continued wastage of resources without assessing the impact on our environment. With more focus on reducing wastage, and driving eco-friendly initiatives, 2020 should be the year when smaller brands make sustainability a key value.

Jacinta Quah
Founder
Jacinta Quah & Co

I would like to see more Purposeful Powerful Leaders developing not just their employees but also taking time to evolve positively to lead their teams better.

Climate change is real as is the momentum to make real impact. We need concerted efforts to make sure that people who are going to lose their jobs in "polluting" industries are reskilled rather than displaced. Everyone has a right to make a living, but we need to place "living" well a priority.

Vijay Kumar
CEO & Founder
ConnectUpz

For 2020, my prediction for the retail sector in Singapore is that more SMEs will adopt digitisation with the help of the newly-set up Heartland Enterprise Centre Singapore (HECS) and IMDA Start Digital Pack. Through the use of technology and data, the trend of retail closures seen in 2019 should see a drastic reduction. I hope the current economic slowdown experienced by developed countries such as Singapore, due to the trade war between the two economic super powers, does not further worsen and can eventually be resolved. Regardless, Singapore is poised to stay resilient though Industry 4.0.

G Rathakrishnan
CEO
London School of Business and Finance

It wasn't a good start to 2020, with the Australian bushfires, and yet another US-led situation in the Middle East. Singapore has been lucky economically in the last decade, and I hope the government does more on the pro-business policy front to uplift businesses, especially SMEs, for the difficult times ahead. I hope not to see another protracted war in the Middle East sparking humanitarian crises, especially affecting women and children.

nitf:lede="true">SYDNEY -- The worst is yet to come for exhausted firefighters battling bushfires raging for the past three days in New South Wales (NSW).</p><p nitf:lede="true">Weather forecasters predict horror winds and soaring temperatures over the weekend, raising fears that the devastation could spread far beyond the 150 homes already destroyed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rural Fire Service (RFS) spokesman Mark Sullivan said firefighters were worried by the outlook for the weekend.</p><p>"It certainly appears from the weather forecast, with very high temperatures and high winds that it certainly could be a nasty couple of days ahead," he said.</p><p>The outlook over the longer term could be even more bleak as the long-range weather forecast for southern New South Wales saw no significant rain over the next 10 days.</p><p>"This will be a protracted campaign … when assets across the board will come under serious threat," Mr Phil Koperberg, the RFS commissioner was quoted as saying.</p><p>"It is a grave situation," he added.</p><p>A thick pall of smoke enveloping Sydney yesterday played havoc with aerial firefighting operations, forcing crews to resort to infra-red satellite technology, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.</p><p>"It's very hard to tell exactly where the fire is because of the enormous amount of smoke," said Mr John Winter, another RFS spokesman.</p><p>As the crisis approached its third day, NSW began receiving assistance from the federal government and other Australian states.</p><p>Around 100 tankers and 500 firefighters from Victoria, Queensland and South Australia were expected to hit the ground over the weekend, said Mr Winter.</p><p>Prime Minister John Howard had earlier offered to make military personnel available even as navy helicopters were deployed to help with spotting fires and conducting evacuations.</p><p>The federal government has also pledged A$1 million (S$960,000) in aid, adding to the fund set up by NSW to help those who have lost their homes.</p><p>According Mr Winter, around 5,000 firefighters could be on the front line at any one time although their total number was much greater.</p><p>"There's up to 15,000 firefighters involved as we repeat people through duty rosters," he said.</p><p>Raging winds coupled with high temperatures and extremely dry conditions over Christmas whipped up the bushfires, many of which were lit deliberately.</p><p>The blazes have left an arc of devastation on a 700 km front around Sydney. So far, no one has died or been seriously injured as a result of the fires, considered the worst since 1994 when four people were killed and 185 homes destroyed.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source
